citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The licensee has not had the attending veterinarian visit the facility annually as written in the program of vet care. The
licensee admitted it’s been a couple of years since his attending vet visited his facility. The licensee must have the
attending veterinarian visit the facility annually.
Correct By May 30, 2023

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A black and white, adult, male rabbit was observed by inspectors sneezing and had white nasal discharge. The licensee
was unaware of the medical issue with this specific rabbit and failed to contact his attending veterinarian.
At least 20 adult rabbits were seen with excessively long nails. A few of the rabbits’ nails were so long it was affecting
their posture and movement. The licensee states he usually trims their nails every 60 days but hasn’t done so recently.
Excessively long toenails can break and cause injury as well as affect the animal’s gate when walking.
Each dealer shall use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose and treat diseases and injuries. The above-
mentioned black and white, adult, male, rabbit must be evaluated by a licensed veterinarian for an accurate diagnosis and
to establish an effective treatment plan. The licensee must ensure that all rabbits always receive adequate veterinary
care. The licensee must trim all the rabbits’ nails and create an appropriate plan to ensure the nails are kept at a proper
length.
Correct By, May 26, 2023

Interior surfaces. In a room housing 40 rabbits there are bare wood support beams between and below the rabbit cages.
The wood is covered in hair, feces, and urine. The concrete floors have an ammonia odor from urine buildup. Indoor
building surfaces in rabbit rooms must be constructed and maintained so that surfaces are impervious to moisture to allow
surfaces to be readily and repeatedly cleaned and sanitized. The bare wood and concrete needs to be sealed or covered
with an impervious surface so that surface can be sanitized.
Correct By June 6, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
Paige Johnson, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
2.40(a)(1) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The licensee has not had the attending veterinarian visit the facility annually as written in the program of vet care. The 
licensee admitted it’s been a couple of years since his attending vet visited his facility. The licensee must have the 
attending veterinarian visit the facility annually. 
Correct By May 30, 2023 
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A black and white, adult, male rabbit was observed by inspectors sneezing and had white nasal discharge. The licensee 
was unaware of the medical issue with this specific rabbit and failed to contact his attending veterinarian.  
At least 20 adult rabbits were seen with excessively long nails. A few of the rabbits’ nails were so long it was affecting 
their posture and movement. The licensee states he usually trims their nails every 60 days but hasn’t done so recently. 
Excessively long toenails can break and cause injury as well as affect the animal’s gate when walking.  
Each dealer shall use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose and treat diseases and injuries. The above-
mentioned black and white, adult, male, rabbit must be evaluated by a licensed veterinarian for an accurate diagnosis and 
to establish an effective treatment plan. The licensee must ensure that all rabbits always receive adequate veterinary 
care. The licensee must trim all the rabbits’ nails and create an appropriate plan to ensure the nails are kept at a proper

length.  
Correct By, May 26, 2023 
3.51(d) 
   
Facilities, indoor. 
Interior surfaces. In a room housing 40 rabbits there are bare wood support beams between and below the rabbit cages. 
The wood is covered in hair, feces, and urine. The concrete floors have an ammonia odor from urine buildup. Indoor 
building surfaces in rabbit rooms must be constructed and maintained so that surfaces are impervious to moisture to allow 
surfaces to be readily and repeatedly cleaned and sanitized. The bare wood and concrete needs to be sealed or covered 
with an impervious surface so that surface can be sanitized.  
Correct By June 6, 2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Paige Johnson, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
